revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Knapp Center | nickname = "The Knapp" | image = The Knapp Center.JPG | image_size = 300px | location = 2601 Forest Avenue
[[Des Moines, Iowa]] 50311 U.S. | broke_ground = 1990 | opened = December 1, 1992 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Drake University]] | operator = [[Drake University]] | surface = Hardwood | construction_cost = $12.5 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|12500000|1992}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = RDG Planning & Design | general_contractor= Taylor Ball Construction Company | former_names = | tenants = [[Drake Bulldogs]] ([[NCAA Division I|NCAA DI]]) (1992–present) | seating_capacity = 7,152 }} The '''Knapp Center''' is a 7,152-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] on the campus of [[Drake University]] in [[Des Moines, Iowa]], United States. It was built in 1992. The Knapp Center is the center building for three athletic buildings combined together. The Bell Center to the west is a general athletic building with offices, a pool, gym, and locker rooms. To the east is the Shivers' Basketball Practice facility, opening in 2014. The Knapp Center itself also holds a weight room by the northwest corner of the basketball court. The namesake of the arena comes from William Knapp, who is the chairman of Iowa Realty and a member of the Drake University Board of Trustees. He played a key role in financing the arena with $3 million gift towards construction.[http://www.godrakebulldogs.com/fls/15700/pdf/11-12-drakembb-lo-res.pdf?SPSID=71126&SPID=8121&DB_OEM_ID=15700 2011-12 Drake Men's Basketball Yearbook] After receiving a donation from [[Hy-Vee]], the court was named in honor of [[East High School (Des Moines)|Des Moines East]] graduate, Drake alum, and the former [[Hy-Vee]] CEO Ron Pearson as "Ron Pearson Court" on September 18, 2010. ==Events== The arena is the home arena for Drake Men's and Women's Basketball and Drake Women's Volleyball. The first Drake Bulldogs basketball game was played on December 5, 1992. The women's basketball team currently has a [[Missouri Valley Conference]] record 16 consecutive home conference wins at the Knapp Center dating back to the 2014-15 season. During the [[Drake Relays]] the arena hosts the Beautiful Bulldog Contest and serves as a media center for athlete interviews along with providing additional locker room and warm-up facilities for athletes. Each May, in addition to Drake University commencement ceremonies the arena hosts numerous area high school graduation ceremonies. The arena has also hosted media & campaign spin rooms during on-campus political debates and hosted various academic lectures, including lectures from [[Maya Angelou]], [[Tim Gunn]], and former President [[Jimmy Carter]]. ==Gallery== Image:Inside_the_Knapp_Center.JPG|Inside the Knapp Center Image:Knapp Center 2010 3.JPG|Inside the Knapp Center during the Iowa vs Drake game on December 18, 2010 ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.godrakebulldogs.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=15700&KEY=&ATCLID=1104484 The Knapp Center - GoDrakeBulldogs.com] *[http://www.shuck-britson.com/projects/pdfs/Drake-Knapp.pdf DRAKE UNIVERSITY KNAPP CENTER - Shuck-Britson] {{Drake Bulldogs men's basketball navbox}} {{Drake University}} {{Missouri Valley Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{coord|41|36|16|N|93|39|7|W|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports in Des Moines, Iowa]] [[Category:Sports venues in Greater Des Moines]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Iowa]] [[Category:Drake Bulldogs men's basketball]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Des Moines, Iowa]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Des Moines, Iowa]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Iowa]] [[Category:1992 establishments in Iowa]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1992]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] {{Iowa-sports-venue-stub}} {{DesMoinesIA-stub}}

|}. ===Multi-division champions=== Fighters who have won championships in multiple weight classes.{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/1205/mma-through-the-years/content.13.html |title=MMA All-time Record Holders |work=sportsillustrated}} Tournament championships and The Ultimate Fighter winners are not included. Randy Couture is the first champion to hold belts in two different divisions, and one of the few to reclaim a title after being defeated. [[Conor McGregor]] was the first fighter to hold multiple titles simultaneously, which he did only briefly due to being stripped of his Featherweight title shortly after capturing the Lightweight. [[Daniel Cormier]] is both the reigning Heavyweight and Light Heavyweight Champions. {| class="wikitable" style="width:99%; text-align:left;" |- !Champion!!Division!!Won!!Lost!!Defenses!!Reign!!Total reign |- |rowspan="5" style="text-align:left"|{{flagicon|USA}} [[Randy Couture]] |rowspan="2"|Heavyweight |Dec 21, 1997 ([[UFC Japan]]) |Jan ?, 1998 (stripped) |style="text-align:center"|0 |style="text-align:center"|{{0}}{{0}}? days |rowspan="5" style="text-align:center"|1,478+ days |- |Nov 17, 2000 ([[UFC 28]]) |Mar 22, 2002 ([[UFC 36]]) |style="text-align:center"|2 |style="text-align:center"|490 days |- |rowspan="2"|Light Heavyweight |Sep 26, 2003 ([[UFC 44]]) |Jan 31, 2004 ([[UFC 46]]) |style="text-align:center"|0 |style="text-align:center"|127 days |- |Aug 21, 2004 ([[UFC 49]]) |Apr 16, 2005 ([[UFC 52]]) |style="text-align:center"|0 |style="text-align:center"|238 days |- |Heavyweight |Mar 3, 2007 ([[UFC 68]]) |Nov 15, 2008 ([[UFC 91]]) |style="text-align:center"|1 |style="text-align:center"|623 days |- |rowspan="2" style="text-align:left"|{{flagicon|USA}} [[B.J. Penn]] |Welterweight |Jan 31, 2004 ([[UFC 46]]) |May 17, 2004 (stripped) |style="text-align:center"|0 |style="text-align:center"|107 days |rowspan="2" style="text-align:center"|919 days |- |Lightweight |Jan 19, 2008 ([[UFC 80]]) |Apr 10, 2010 ([[UFC 112]]) |style="text-align:center"|3 |style="text-align:center"|812 days |- |rowspan="2" style="text-align:left"|{{flagicon|IRE}} [[Conor McGregor]] |Featherweight |Dec 12, 2015 ([[UFC 194]]) |Nov 26, 2016 (stripped) |style="text-align:center"|0 |style="text-align:center"|350 days |rowspan="2" style="text-align:center"|862 days

revision.text:
This is a list of '''foreign players''' in the top flight of [[Norwegian football]], currently known as '''[[Eliteserien]]''', which commenced play in 1937. The following players must meet both of the following two criteria: #Have played at least one Eliteserien game. Players who were signed by Eliteserien clubs, but only played in lower league, cup and/or European games, or did not play in any competitive games at all, are not included. #Are considered foreign, determined by the following: ::A player is considered foreign if he is not eligible to play for [[Norway national football team]], more specifically: ::*If a player has been capped on international level, the national team is used; if he has been capped by more than one country, the highest level (or the most recent) team is used. ::*If a player has not been capped on international level, his country of birth is used, except those who were born abroad from Norwegian parents or moved to Norway at a young age, and those who clearly indicated to have switched his nationality to another nation.
<center> {{inc-sport}}</center>
{{TOC right}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox Stadium | name = Louis Guisto Field | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = | location = De La Salle Drive and Saint Mary's Parkway, [[Moraga, CA]], [[United States|USA]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.841512|-122.111953|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = 2011–12 | opened = February 17, 2012 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Saint Mary's College of California]] | operator = Saint Mary's College of California | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = 330 feet ([[Left field]])
375 feet (LCF)
400 feet ([[Baseball field#outfield|Center field]])
375 feet (RCF)
330 feet ([[Right field]]) | acreage = | tenants = [[Saint Mary's Gaels baseball]] (2012–present) }} '''Louis Guisto Field''' is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Moraga, California|Moraga]], [[California]], [[United States|USA]]. It is home to the [[Saint Mary's Gaels baseball]] team of the [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[West Coast Conference]]. Opened in 2012, the venue replaced [[Louis Guisto Field (1928)|the old Louis Guisto Field]] (the location of which was behind the third base line of the new facility){{cite web|last=Sorenson |first=Eric |title=It Was THAT Kind of Day for BYU |url=http://blogs.eastonbaseball.com/collegebaseballtoday/2012/02/23/it-was-that-kind-of-day-for-byu/ |work=College Baseball Today |accessdate=February 26, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65kRzIdp8?url=http://blogs.eastonbaseball.com/collegebaseballtoday/2012/02/23/it-was-that-kind-of-day-for-byu/ |archivedate=February 26, 2012 |date=February 23, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} as the home of Saint Mary's baseball. Like the old facility, it is named for former Saint Mary's baseball player and coach Louis Guisto.{{cite web|title=Saint Mary's College Athletic Facilities |url=http://www.smcgaels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=21400&ATCLID=1483015 |work=SMC Gaels |accessdate=August 24, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230125900/http://www.smcgaels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=21400&ATCLID=1483015 |archivedate=December 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The field opened on February 17, 2012, when Saint Mary's defeated [[Southern Utah Thunderbirds baseball|Southern Utah]] 2–1 in front of 1,100 fans.{{cite web |title=Southern Utah vs Saint Mary's (CA) (Feb 17, 2012) |url=http://www.smcgaels.com/downloads2/447288.htm?ATCLID=205382130&SPSID=101607&SPID=12533&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=21400 |work=SMCGaels.com |accessdate=February 26, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65kSY2TCh?url=http://www.smcgaels.com/downloads2/447288.htm?ATCLID=205382130&SPSID=101607&SPID=12533&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=21400 |archivedate=February 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Former Major League pitcher [[Tom Candiotti]] (Saint Mary's Class of 1979) threw out the honorary first pitch.{{cite web|title=Gaels End Historic Day With a Win |url=http://www.smcgaels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=101607&SPID=12533&DB_LANG=C&ATCLID=205382130&DB_OEM_ID=21400 |work=SMCGaels.com |accessdate=February 26, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908003528/http://www.smcgaels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=101607&SPID=12533&DB_LANG=C&ATCLID=205382130&DB_OEM_ID=21400 |archivedate=September 8, 2015 |date=February 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Following the 2012 season, construction on the facility will enter its second phase. During this period, a grandstand with a capacity of 1,500 spectators will be added.{{cite web|title=Saint Mary's College Athletics Facilities |url=http://www.smcgaels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=21400&ATCLID=1483015 |work=SMCGaels.com |accessdate=February 26, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230125900/http://www.smcgaels.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=21400&ATCLID=1483015 |archivedate=December 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The old facility will be razed, and a building housing a swimming pool, team offices, and training rooms will be built in its place. == See also == * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] == References == {{reflist}} {{West Coast Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{California NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in California]] [[Category:Saint Mary's Gaels baseball]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in California]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Old Dominion Soccer Complex | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Old Dominion Soccer Complex.jpeg | image_size = 250px | caption = | fullname = | former_names = ODU Soccer Stadium | location = 1500 West 43rd Street
[[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]], [[Virginia]], [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|36.88402|-76.31085 |format=dms |region:US-VA_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1990 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Old Dominion University]] | operator = Old Dominion University | surface = Natural Grass | scoreboard = Electronic | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = {{convert|380|ft|m}} x {{convert|245|ft|m}} | acreage = | tenants = [[Old Dominion Monarchs soccer|Old Dominion Monarchs Men's and Women's soccer]] Stihl Soccer Classic | website = [http://www.odusports.com/PhotoAlbum.dbml?&PALBID=935847&DB_OEM_ID=31100 Official site] }} The '''Old Dominion Soccer Complex''' is a [[soccer-specific stadium]] located on the campus of [[Old Dominion University]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia]], [[United States|USA]]. The 4,000-seat stadium is home to the [[Old Dominion Monarchs and Lady Monarchs]] [[Old Dominion Monarchs soccer|soccer]] teams. The Monarchs compete in [[Conference USA]]. The stadium is also the host of the annual Stihl/ODU Soccer Classic.{{cite web|last=Hudson Jr.|first=Carol|title=ODU Stihl Classic This Weekend|url=http://www.topdrawersoccer.com/college-soccer-articles/odu-stihl-classic-this-weekend_aid25651|work=Top Drawer Soccer|accessdate=14 July 2013}} The stadium opened in 1990 replacing the university's football stadium, [[Foreman Field]], as the home of Old Dominion soccer.{{cite web|title=2018 ODU Men's Soccer Media Guide and Record Book|url=http://www.odusports.com//attachments1/files/31100/638654.pdf?SPSID=750443&SPID=127316&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=31100|publisher=Old Dominion Athletics|accessdate=2 November 2018}} The opening game was a 1-1 tie against the [[College of William and Mary]] with 3200 fans in attendance.{{cite web|title=Jim Jarrett timeline and accomplishments as athletic director|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/oldd/genrel/auto_pdf/jarrett-timeline.pdf|work=Old Dominion University Athletics|publisher=Old Dominion University|accessdate=14 July 2013}} Between the 2002 and 2005 seasons, the Monarchs men's soccer team had a 32 match regular season unbeaten streak at the complex.{{cite web|title=#2 Men's Soccer Falls to JMU 2-1 in Overtime|url=http://www.odusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=31100&ATCLID=208383763|publisher=Old Dominion Athletics|accessdate=15 July 2013}} The stadium has hosted the 1991, 1992, and 2005 [[CAA Men's Soccer Tournament|Colonial Athletic Association Men's Soccer Tournaments]],{{cite web|title=2012 CAA Men's Soccer Championship Program|url=http://www.nmnathletics.com/fls/8500/supportfiles/pdf/1213ChampPrgms/12MSOC_ChampPrgm.pdf?DB_OEM_ID=8500|publisher=Colonial Athletic Conference|accessdate=14 July 2013}} along with [[NCAA College Cup]] games in 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2017. The complex has also hosted the 2014 and 2017 [[Conference USA Men's Soccer Tournament]]s which were both won by the home standing Monarchs.{{cite web|title=Soccer Monarchs Rule As C-USA Champions|url=http://www.odusports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=750443&SPID=127316&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=31100&ATCLID=209768249|website=ODUsports.com|publisher=ODU Athletics|accessdate=25 December 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Conference USA soccer venue navbox}} {{Old Dominion University}} {{Hampton Roads Sports}} [[Category:Old Dominion Monarchs and Lady Monarchs]] [[Category:Old Dominion Monarchs soccer]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Norfolk, Virginia]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Virginia]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1990]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox union <!-- Please include all unused fields for future use. See [[template talk:Infobox Union]] for usage. --> |name= PHPA |country= [[Canada]], [[United States]] |affiliation= |members= 1,600 |full_name= Professional Hockey Players' Association |native_name= |image=<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:PHPA PRIMARY.png|300px]] --> |founded=1967 |current= |Executive Director= Larry Landon |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]] |people= |website= {{URL|http://www.phpa.com}} |footnotes= }} The '''Professional Hockey Players' Association''', or '''PHPA''', is the labor union that represents the interests of hockey players in the [[American Hockey League]] and [[ECHL]], the two largest minor leagues in North American professional [[ice hockey]]. Established in 1967, the PHPA is one of the oldest players' unions in professional sports and the only minor league Players' Association within a major league sport. Recognized by the US [[National Labor Relations Board]] as the certified [[bargaining unit]] for all members enrolled in the Association, the main function of the PHPA is to negotiate and protect various player benefits by way of a [[Collective Bargaining Agreement]]. These benefits include: health and welfare benefits, training camp allowances, travel and trade relocation expenses, per diem, housing allowances, play-off shares, licensing rights, revenue-sharing, and membership assistance programs.
==History== The Professional Hockey Player's Association was founded in 1967 in [[Portland, Oregon]], when members of the [[Portland Buckaroos]] (of the now defunct [[Western Hockey League (1952–1974)|Western Hockey League]] (WHL)) recognized that Canadians playing hockey in the United States who were starting families would send their wives home to Canada to give birth to their babies. [[Medicare (Canada)|Canada's social insurance system]] would cover the expense for Canadian citizens in Canada, but the teams provided no coverage usable in the U.S. A number of Portland Buckaroos, including Doug Messier, Arlo Goodwin, and teammates, led the group and hired Portland attorney Curt Leichner as their legal counsel to legally form a WHL Players Association to allow WHL players to take advantage of group pension and health care plans, gaining better benefits through strength in numbers.
Over the course of the 1967–68 season, players from the [[American Hockey League]] saw the benefit of forming a “benevolent society” of their own and approached their WHL counterparts with the vision of creating one players' association which would represent all professional hockey players outside of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL). On May 20, 1968, WHL and AHL players voted to form the “Professional Hockey Players’ Association".
After the 1973–74 season, former WHL President [[Max McNab]] became the fourth President of the [[Central Hockey League (1963–1984)|Central Hockey League]] (CHL), a developmental league for professional minor league hockey players, which featured some teams that were affiliates for various NHL clubs. With a number of former WHL executives at the helm of the CHL, players were eager to organize a collective voice and become members of the PHPA. A small group of elected CHL player representatives was invited to the PHPA’s annual meeting of player representatives to discuss the application to the PHPA among player representatives from the WHL and AHL. On May 17, 1974, a motion was passed whereby the CHL players' application for membership into the PHPA was accepted. CHL players were represented by the PHPA until 1984, when the league folded.
The WHL folded in 1974, citing financial pressures resulting from the WHL’s prime venues being taken by the expansion practices of the NHL and [[World Hockey Association]] (WHA). The PHPA remained healthy as it still represented players in two leagues, the AHL and CHL.
In 1985, players in the former [[International Hockey League (1945–2001)]] (IHL) petitioned the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) to join the PHPA. IHL owners accepted the PHPA as the recognized bargaining unit for IHL players without the need for a formal NLRB vote.
In 1991, Larry Landon was asked by the PHPA Executive Committee to succeed Curt Leichner, who was preparing for retirement, as the new Executive Director. Landon assumed the role of Deputy Executive Director until 1993, when he officially assumed control of the PHPA. Landon then moved the PHPA office from Portland, Oregon, to St. Catharines, Ontario.
In 1994, a group of players from the [[East Coast Hockey League]] approached Landon about being represented by the PHPA. At the 1994 PHPA Annual Meeting of Player Representatives, AHL and IHL player representatives unanimously approved the effort to unionize the ECHL, and during the 1994-95 season, PHPA staff initiated efforts to represent ECHL players. Eventually, on March 17, 1995, the NLRB conducted a formal, secret ballot vote among players in each ECHL city. The result was an overwhelming response from the players in favor of unionizing the ECHL, with the first PHPA-ECHL CBA finalized in October 1995.
By 2000, the AHL had a dramatically different look, as almost half of its twenty teams were new, and attendance had almost doubled since 1994. The IHL meanwhile, suffering from significant contraction and challenges in many of its markets, folded in 2001.
During the 2007–08 season, players in the [[Central Hockey League]] (CHL) approached the PHPA with interest in PHPA representation of CHL players. On April 1, 2008, the NLRB recognized the PHPA as the official bargaining unit for CHL players, after a secret-ballot vote conducted by the NLRB. The league and PHPA reached an inaugural CBA in October 2009, which was retained until the CHL and ECHL consolidated in 2014.
In 2010, the PHPA relocated its headquarters to [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]].
Currently, the PHPA represents approximately 1,600 players across 58 teams throughout the AHL and ECHL, which are the premier player development leagues for the NHL.
==Organization== The PHPA’s management is led by Executive Director Larry Landon, who heads an Executive Committee of player representatives from the AHL and ECHL. For every five teams in a league, one player representative may be added to the Executive Committee. The Committee assists the Executive Director in providing direction and oversight in dealing with various matter of importance to the Association and its membership, including budgetary matters, player issues, strategic planning, and other business affairs.
==External links== * [http://www.phpa.com Professional Hockey Players' Association] * [http://www.theahl.com American Hockey League] * [http://www.echl.com ECHL]
[[Category:Trade unions in Canada]] [[Category:Trade unions in the United States]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1967]] [[Category:Sports trade unions]] [[Category:Minor league hockey]] [[Category:Niagara Falls, Ontario]] [[Category:Organizations based in Ontario]]

{{Use Australian English|date=September 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox racecourse |name = Randwick Racecourse |image = [[File:Royal Randwick Racecourse.jpg|250px]] |caption = Randwick Racecourse from above |website = http://www.australianturfclub.com.au/ |location = [[Eastern Suburbs (Sydney)|Eastern Suburbs]], [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] |coordinates = {{coord|33|54|39|S|151|13|49|E|region:AU-NSW_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |owner = [[Australian Turf Club]] |opened = 1833[http://www.australianturfclub.com.au/ Randwick Racecourse official website] |track = |closed = |channel = |racetype = |coursetype = |notableraces = [[The Everest]]
[[Australian Derby]]
[[Doncaster Handicap]]
[[Queen Elizabeth Stakes (ATC)|Queen Elizabeth Stakes]] }} [[Image:Randwick Racecourse Track.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Randwick Racecourse on Derby Day 2007]] [[File:Poitrel 1920 AJC Randwick Plate Trainer Harry Robinson.jpg|thumb|250px|Randwick Racecourse on Randwick Plate Day 1920]] [[File:1952 Randwick Racecourse Sydney Members Stand & Enclosure.jpg|thumb|250px|Members stand and enclosure in 1952.]] [[Image:Randwick Racecourse, Sydney , 1863 by unknown photographer from The State Library of New South Wales.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Randwick Racecourse in 1863]] [[File:1952 Randwick Racecourse Sydney Tramway Exit Bridge.jpg|thumb|250px|The racecourse tramway exit bridge in 1952.]] [[File:Randwick racecourse 1920.jpg|thumb|250px|Former 1920 racecourse tram station and southern exit at Ascot Street.]] [[Image:WYD08 FinalMass.JPG|thumb|250px|The Final Mass for [[World Youth Day 2008]] was held at Randwick Racecourse (dubbed ''Southern Cross Precinct'' specifically for the event) and was attended by 350,000[http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/07/20/pope.australia.ap/index.html CNN Reports on WYD08] people.]] '''Royal Randwick Racecourse''' is a [[racecourse]] for [[horse racing]] located in the [[Eastern Suburbs (Sydney)|Eastern Suburbs]] of [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]]. Randwick Racecourse is [[Crown Land]][http://23.101.218.132/Prod/parlment/hansart.nsf/V3Key/LC20110823015?Open&refNavID=HA8_1 NSW Parliament - AJC & STC Merger Amendment Bill 2011] leased to the [[Australian Turf Club]] and known to many Sydney racegoers as headquarters. The racecourse is located approximately six kilometres from the [[Sydney Central Business District]] in the suburb of [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]]. The course proper has a circumference of 2224m with a home straight of 410m.[http://theraceguide.com.au/tracks/3-royal-randwick Royal Randwick - The Race Guide] On the 14th October, 2017, the inaugural running of [[The Everest]] was held at Royal Randwick. The Everest is the richest race in Australia and the richest turf race in the world with $10 million in prize money.{{Cite web|url=https://www.australianturfclub.com.au/21097-2/|title=The Everest, World’s Richest Turf Event|website=www.australianturfclub.com.au|language=en|access-date=2017-11-27}} Since 2014, Randwick hosts The Championships, a two-day season-ending meeting in April that offers over AUD$20 million in prize money.[http://www.thechampionships.com.au/the-event.aspx The Championships] It features several Group 1 races such as the [[Australian Derby]], [[Doncaster Handicap]] and [[Queen Elizabeth Stakes (ATC)|Queen Elizabeth Stakes]]. Other annual events include the [[Sydney Carnival]], Spring Carnival[http://www.visitnsw.com/events/sydney-spring-carnival Sydney Spring Carnival - Randwick] and the Chinese Festival of Racing.[https://www.australianturfclub.com.au/chinese-festival-of-racing-welcomed-to-royal-randwick/ Chinese Festival of Racing] == History == In January 1833, NSW Governor [[Richard Bourke]] designated the land for use as a racecourse. Up until then, [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]] in the [[Sydney]] CBD had been the main venue for racing within the city. The first race held at Randwick was a private event held in June 1833. The course was originally known as the 'Sandy Course' due to the condition of the ground. In 1840 racing ceased at the venue and was only used for training. In the early 1840s, the Australian Jockey Club (AJC) was formed and in 1860 moved its headquarters to Randwick. In May of that year, racing resumed at the venue with a crowd of 6,000 people attending. In 1863 the land was officially granted to the AJC and was held until 2011 when the AJC and the Sydney Turf Club (STC) merged to become the [[Australian Turf Club]] (ATC). The ATC are the current operators of Royal Randwick Racecourse.''[http://www2.sl.nsw.gov.au/archive/discover_collections/society_art/races/randwick/ Royal Randwick Racecourse]'' - Archive from the State Library of New South Wales ==='Royal' Randwick=== On the 22nd February, 1992, Queen Elizabeth II visited Randwick Racecourse[http://www.upi.com/Archives/1992/02/18/Queen-Elizabeth-Prince-Philip-arrive-in-Australia/4987698389200/ Queen Elizabeth, Prince Philip arrive in Australia ] and opened the Paddock Stand. On this date, upon request, the Queen granted permission for the venue to be known as Royal Randwick. From this date the venue was officially able to be referred to as 'Royal Randwick'. An extract from a letter from [[Kenneth Scott (courtier)]], Deputy Private Secretary to Queen Elizabeth II, to the club reads: "You do not need me to tell you how much The Queen and The Duke of Edinburgh enjoyed their visit to the Royal Randwick Racecourse today. Her Majesty was particularly glad that she was able, on this occasion, to legitimise your traditional title of "Royal" and to open a very handsome new Grandstand." == Races == The following is a list of [[Group races]] which are contested at Randwick Racecourse. {| class="wikitable" |- |'''Grp''' |'''Race Name''' |'''Age''' |'''Sex''' |'''Weight''' |'''Distance''' |'''Date''' |- |1 |[[Australian Derby]] |3YO |Open |sw |2400 |April |- |1 |[[AJC Oaks]] |3YO |Fillies |sw |2400 |April |- |1 |[[AJC Queen Elizabeth Stakes]] |Open |Open |wfa |2000 |April |- |1 |[[AJC Sires Produce Stakes]] |2YO |Open |sw |1400 |April |- |1 |[[All Aged Stakes]] |Open |Open |wfa |1400 |April |- |1 |[[Canterbury Stakes]] |3YO+ |Open |wfa |1300 |March |- |1 |[[Champagne Stakes (Australia)|Champagne Stakes]] |2YO |Open |sw |1600 |April |- |1 |[[Doncaster Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |1600 |April |- |1 |[[Epsom Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |1600 |October |- |1 |[[Flight Stakes]] |3YO |Fillies |sw |1600 |October |- |1 |[[George Main Stakes]] |Open |Open |wfa |1600 |September |- |1 |[[Queen Of The Turf Stakes]] |3YO+ |F&M |qlty |1600 |April |- |1 |[[Randwick Guineas]] |3YO |Open |sw |1600 |March |- |1 |[[Spring Champion Stakes]] |3YO |Open |sw |2000 |October |- |1 |[[Sydney Cup]] |Open |Open |hcp |3200 |April |- |1 |[[T J Smith Stakes]] |Open |Open |wfa |1200 |April |- |1 |[[AJC Metropolitan Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |2400 |October |- |1 |[[Chipping Norton Stakes]] |Open |Open |wfa |1600 |February |- |2 |[[AJC Chairmans Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |2600 |April |- |2 |[[Breeders' Classic]] |4YO+ |Mares |sw+p |1200 |February |- |2 |[[Challenge Stakes (ATC)|Challenge Stakes]] |3YO+ |Open |wfa |1000 |March |- |2 |[[Chelmsford Stakes]] |Open |Open |wfa |1600 |September |- |2 |[[Emancipation Stakes]] |3YO+ |F&M |sw+p |1600 |April |- |2 |[[Furious Stakes]] |3YO |Fillies |sw |1400 |September |- |2 |[[Hobartville Stakes]] |3YO |Open |sw |1400 |April |- |2 |[[Light Fingers Stakes]] |3YO |Fillies |sw+p |1100 |February |- |2 |[[Roman Consul Stakes]] |3YO |Open |sw |1200 |September |- |2 |[[Royal Sovereign Stakes]] |3YO |C&G |sw+p |1200 |February |- |2 |[[Sapphire Stakes (Australia)|Sapphire Stakes]] |Open |F&M |sw+p |1200 |April |- |2 |[[Stan Fox Stakes]] |3YO |Open |sw |1400 |September |- |2 |[[The Shorts (ATC)|The Shorts]] |3YO+ |Open |sw+p |1100 |September |- |2 |[[Villiers Stakes]] |Open |Open |hcp |1600 |December |- |3 |[[Adrian Knox Stakes]] |3YO |Fillies |qlty |2000 |April |- |3 |[[Bill Ritchie Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |1400 |September |- |3 |[[Canonbury Stakes]] |2YO |C&G |sw +p |1100 |February |- |3 |[[Colin Stephen Quality Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |2400 |September |- |3 |[[Craven Plate]] |Open |Open |wfa |2000 |October |- |3 |[[Frank Packer Plate]] |3YO |Open |sw |2000 |April |- |3 |[[Southern Cross Stakes]] |Open |Open |hcp |1200 |February |- |3 |[[Kindergarten Stakes]] |2YO |Open |sw |1100 |March |- |3 |[[Randwick Plate]] |Open |Open |hcp |2000 |March |- |3 |[[San Domenico Stakes]] |3YO |Open |sw |1000 |August |- |3 |[[Skyline Stakes]] |2YO |C&G |sw |1200 |March |- |3 |[[South Pacific Classic]] |3YO |Open |sw |1400 |April |- |3 |[[Summer Cup (horse racing)|Summer Cup]] |Open |Open |hcp |2400 |December |- |3 |[[Sweet Embrace Stakes]] |2YO |Fillies |sw |1200 |March |- |3 |[[Tramway Quality Handicap]] |Open |Open |hcp |1400 |September |} == Venue == Besides horseracing, Randwick Racecourse has been used as a venue for many other events including [[concert]]s and religious [[Mass (liturgy)|mass]]es. In 1970, [[Pope Paul VI]] celebrated [[Mass (liturgy)|mass]] at RandwickSearch under Manuscripts and Pictures on [http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/ New South Wales library] for "Australian tour of Pope Paul VI Randwick" as part of his pastoral visit to Australia. The Racecourse was also the site of a [[Mass (liturgy)|mass]] held by [[Pope John Paul II]] in 1995 for the [[Beatification]] ceremony of Australia's first potential saint [[Mary MacKillop]]. It was also the site of the vigil and final mass of [[World Youth Day 2008]] in July 2008. Racing was stopped for several weeks, due to the alterations needed to hold over 400,000 people. This move had been opposed by the Randwick Trainers Association, which holds lease interests over some areas intended to be used for the event.[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2007/10/04/1191091276220.html Back off, irate horse trainers warn Pell] The dispute was resolved,''[http://www.ajc.com.au/mediaandnews/newsarticle.aspx?ID=148 World Youth Day reaches agreement with racing industry]'' - Article on Australian Jockey Club website by the [[Government of Australia|federal government]] and the [[Government of New South Wales|state government]] jointly pledging $40 million as reimbursement to the racing industry.''[http://au.news.yahoo.com/071115/2/14xhu.html Racing industry offered payout for Pope] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20071204033135/http://au.news.yahoo.com/071115/2/14xhu.html |date=4 December 2007 }}'' - Article on au.news.yahoo.com The famous racecourse has also appeared in several films, including ''[[Mission: Impossible 2]]''.[https://www.imdb.com/search/title?locations=Royal%20Randwick%20Racecourse,%20Sydney,%20New%20South%20Wales,%20Australia&ref_=ttloc_loc_13 IMDb: Movies Filmed at Royal Randwick] Randwick Racecourse is also used as an exam venue by the [[University of New South Wales]]. In addition, the annual [[Future Music Festival]] was held at the racecourse from 2006"[http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s4107581.htm Future music festival announces 2015 dates]" - Article on ABC Website until it was cancelled in 2015"[http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/future-music-festival-is-over-it-will-not-return-in-2016-says-mushroom-group-20150402-1mdkfq.html Future Music Festival is Over]" - Article on smh.com.au ===Buildings & Spaces=== ====Queen Elizabeth II Grandstand: 2013 - Present==== The [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] (QEII) Grandstand is the main [[grandstand]] building. Originally constructed in 1969, it was torn down to its bare structure and rebuilt into the current state in 2012 and reopened to the public in 2013. It is 110m in length and 6 storeys high.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ====Official / Members Stand: 1886 - Present==== The Official / Members Stand was constructed in 1886 and still remains today although it has been extended and modified multiple times, in 1907, 1914 and 1920.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ====Theatre of the Horse (ToTH): 2013 - Present==== The Theatre of the Horse, also known as the "ToTH", is an outdoor auditorium for the presentation of thoroughbred racehorses both before and after a race. The ToTH is linked to the track-front via an underground tunnel in which the horses access the track. The ToTH has a capacity of 4,500 and is also used for live music events and functions. The construction of the ToTH was not without controversy, many racegoers have criticised the space for not being located trackside. ====Saddling Paddock Tote Building: 1917 - Present==== The Saddling Paddock Tote Building, known as the Octagonal bar, is located behind the main grandstand. It was initially constructed in 1917 to house a [[Tote Board|Totalisator]], the fourth in the world to be installed. The building is now used as an event space and a bar on race days.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ====Owners Pavilion: 2013 - Present==== The Owners Pavilion is located directly adjacent to the Theatre of the Hose and is a private space for racehorse owners. The pavilion was constructed at the same time as the new QEII Grandstand and ToTH.[https://www.australianturfclub.com.au/royal-randwick/owners-pavilion/ Australian Turf Club: Owners Pavilion] ====Paddock Stand: 1992 - 2012==== The Paddock Stand replaced the St Ledger Stand and Grandstand and was a two-storey, long, horizontal structure. The stand was formally opened by Queen Elizabeth II in February 1992, it was also on this occasion that the Queen certified Randwick as "Royal". The Paddock Stand was demolished in 2012 to make way for the new QEII Grandstand.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ====Tea House: 1914 - 2012==== The Tea House was a large structure at 50m long, 27m wide and two storeys high and could accommodate 1,000 racegoers. The original Tea house burnt down in 1917 and was immediately reconstructed to the same specifications.[http://www.smh.com.au/nsw/storm-in-a-tea-house-as-randwick-ignores-past-20111026-1mk36.html Article on SMH: Storm in a Tea House as Randwick ignores past] The Tea House was demolished in 2012 as part of the upgrades to the current layout.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ====Ladies Stand: 1910 - 1998==== The Ladies Stand, also known as the Queens or Royal Stand was constructed in 1910[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] and remained until 1998. ====First Grandstand: 1860 - 1875==== The First Grandstand was constructed for the first race meeting at Randwick and was made of American timber. Designed by John Hilly, it was intended to be temporary but stood for 15 years.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ====Second Grandstand: 1876 - 1988==== The Second Grandstand, also known as the Paddock Stand, was constructed to replace the initial grandstand constructed on site. It was extended in 1907 and 1914 and remained for more than 100 years to 1988 when it was demolished to make way for the new Paddock Stand.[https://www.thoroughbredracing.com/articles/racecourse-architecture-royal-randwick/ Racecourse Architecture: Royal Randwick] ==Gallery== File:SAM_0673.jpg|Royal Randwick, Grandstand at left File:SAM_0703.jpg|The [[teahouse|Tea House]] File:SAM_0708.jpg|Tea House and Rose Garden File:SAM_0702.jpg|Skyline and Tea House viewed from Grandstand == See also == {{stack|{{Portal|Horse racing|Sydney}}}} * [[List of Australian organisations with royal patronage]] * [[Big Stable Newmarket]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5102339 Randwick Racecourse, ''Australian Town and Country Journal'', (Saturday, 25 September 1886), p.661;] [http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71067921 ''Australian Town and Country Journal'', (Saturday, 25 September 1886), p.654.] * {{cite web | url = http://dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/randwick_racecourse | title = Randwick Racecourse | accessdate = 29 September 2015 | author = Mark Dunn | date = 2008 | work=[[Dictionary of Sydney]]}} [[[Creative Commons license|CC-By-SA]]] {{SydneyRacing}} {{Sydney landmarks}} ==External links== {{Commons category| Randwick racecourse }} *[http://www.australianturfclub.com.au Australian Turf Club] [[Category:Horse racing venues in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Sydney]] [[Category:Randwick Racecourse]] [[Category:1833 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1833]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{coord|53|23|59.54|N|1|25|7.54|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | name = FlyDSA Arena | logo_image = | image = The Sheffield Arena.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = Exterior view of venue under former signage (c.2007) | address = Broughton Ln
[[Sheffield]] S9 2DF
[[England]] | coordinates = | opened = 30 May 1991 | renovated = 2013 | owner = [[Sheffield City Trust]] | operator = [[Live Nation UK]] | construction_cost= £34 million | former_names = Sheffield Arena (1991–2002, 2007–10, 2015–17)
Hallam FM Arena (2002–07)
Motorpoint Arena (2010–15) | seating_type = | seating_capacity = 13,600
4,520 {{small|(Steel Hall)}} | tenants = [[Sheffield Steelers]] {{small|([[Elite Ice Hockey League|EIHL]]) (1991-present)}} | website = {{URL|www.flydsaarena.co.uk|Venue Website}} }} '''FlyDSA Arena''' (originally known as '''Sheffield Arena''') is an [[arena]] located in [[Sheffield]], [[England]]. It is situated near [[Rotherham]], [[Sheffield]] City Centre, [[Meadowhall Centre|Meadowhall]] and the [[Valley Centertainment|Centertainment]]. Opened in 1991, it is used for concerts and sporting events, and is also home to the [[Sheffield Steelers]] [[ice hockey]] club. Attendance for all events at the venue has totaled around 7 million since its opening. It has a maximum capacity of 13,600.http://www.motorpointarenasheffield.co.uk/arena-information/technical-specifications/#_seating-capacity ==History== The arena opened as Sheffield Arena in May 1991 and was renamed [[Hallam FM]] Arena in 2002, but returned to its original name from 1 November 2007.{{cite web|author=Motorpoint Arena |url=http://www.hallamfmarena.co.uk/ |title=Welcome to the Sheffield Arena |publisher=Hallamfmarena.co.uk |accessdate=7 May 2011}} On 9 August 2010, Sheffield Arena was officially renamed Motorpoint Arena Sheffield, after the [[Derby]] based car sales company invested £1 million to rename the venue.{{cite news |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/video/1m-new-name-drives-Motorpoint.6465197.jp/ |title=£1m new name drives Motorpoint Arena Sheffield |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219172806/http://www.thestar.co.uk/video/1m-new-name-drives-Motorpoint.6465197.jp/ |archivedate=19 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In July 2013, the arena underwent a major renovation and now has a new roof, doors, seats, lighting, catering and toilet facilities. In August 2015 the arena was once again rebranded as Sheffield Arena, however in September 2017 nearby [[Doncaster Sheffield Airport]] began sponsoring the arena giving it a rebrand, FlyDSA Arena. ===Opening and Labour's Sheffield rally=== Constructed at a cost of [[Pound sterling|£]]34 million, it was opened by [[Elizabeth II|Queen Elizabeth II]] on 30 May 1991.{{cite web|url=http://www.flydsaarena.co.uk/arena-information/about-flydsa-arena/ |title=About the Sheffield Arena |publisher=FlyDSA Arena |accessdate=22 September 2017}} The first concert took place that evening, [[Paul Simon]] playing as part of his "Born at the Right Time" tour. The arena then took on the role of Gymnastics Hall for the [[1991 Summer Universiade|1991 World Student Games]] which were held in the city and which prompted the investment in, and development of, both the arena and nearby [[Don Valley Stadium]]. The arena was the location for the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]]'s 1992 [[Sheffield Rally]]. Attended by over 10,000 party members and the entire shadow cabinet. Held just before that year's general election, which Labour was widely expected to win, the event is often seen as a factor in the party's defeat.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/special/politics97/background/pastelec/92keyiss.shtml |title=Key Issues in the 1992 Campaign|work= BBC News, Politics '97}} While the event was seen as a success to those within the hall, many commentators, and Labour politicians, viewing it as triumphalist in nature. However, it has also been asserted that the event had negligible impact on the outcome,{{cite book|last=Westlake|first= Martin |year=2001|title=Kinnock: The Biography|pages=560–564}} with a fall in the party's support having already occurred.{{cite news|first=Jim |last=Parish |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/199901010027 |title=It was tax what lost it for Labour|work=New Statesman|date=1 January 1999|accessdate=}} == Entertainment == {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- ! colspan="8"|Entertainment events held at the Sheffield Arena |- ! width=50| Year ! width=100| Date ! width=150| Nationalities ! width=200| Artists ! width=300| Events ! width=200| Supporting Acts ! width=100| Attendance ! width=100| Box Office |- ! 1994 | 14 November | Swedish | [[Roxette]] |-[Crash Boom Bang] ! rowspan="2"|1995 | 4 April | United States | [[Janet Jackson]] | [[Janet World Tour]] | [[MN8]] |- | 3 December | United Kingdom | [[David Bowie]] | [[Outside Tour]] |- ! 1997 | 8 September | United States | [[Toni Braxton]] | [[Secrets Tour]] | N/A | colspan="2" {{Unknown}} |- ! 1998 | 4 June | United States | [[Janet Jackson]] | [[The Velvet Rope Tour]] | [[Another Level (band)|Another Level]] |- ! 1999 | 11 December | United States | [[Cher]] | [[Believe Tour]] |- ! rowspan="3"|2001 | 6 March | rowspan="3"|[[Ireland]] | rowspan="3"|[[Westlife]] | rowspan="3"|[[Where Dreams Come True Tour]] |- | 7 March |- | 8 March |- ! rowspan="7"|2002 | 1 May | rowspan="5"|Ireland | rowspan="5"|Westlife | rowspan="5"|[[World of Our Own Tour]] |- | 2 May |- | 3 May |- | 4 May |- | 5 May |- | 14 May | rowspan="2"|Australia | rowspan="2"|[[Kylie Minogue]] | rowspan="2"|[[KylieFever2002]] |- | 15 May |- ! rowspan="4"|2003 | 18 July | rowspan="4"|Ireland | rowspan="4"|Westlife | rowspan="4"|[[Unbreakable Tour (Westlife concert tour)|Unbreakable Tour]] |- | 19 July |- | 21 July |- | 22 July |- ! rowspan="6"|2004 | 13 February | rowspan="2"|Canada | rowspan="2"|[[Shania Twain]] | rowspan="2"|[[Up! Tour]] | rowspan="2"|Björn Againe |- | 8 March |- | 29 April | rowspan="3"|Ireland | rowspan="3"|Westlife | rowspan="3"|[[The No 1's Tour]] |- | 30 April |- | 1 May |- | 19 May | United States | [[Cher]] | [[The Farewell Tour]] |- ! rowspan="2"|2005 | 18 March | rowspan="2"|Ireland | rowspan="2"|Westlife | rowspan="2"|[[Back Home Tour]] |- | 19 March |- ! rowspan="2"|2006 | 27 April | rowspan="2"|Ireland | rowspan="2"|Westlife | rowspan="2"|[[Face to Face Tour]] |- | 28 April |- ! rowspan="3"|2007 | 13 March | rowspan="2"|Ireland | rowspan="2"|Westlife | rowspan="2"|[[The Love Tour]] |- | 14 March |- | 7 December | Barbados | [[Rihanna]] | [[Good Girl Gone Bad Tour]] |- ! rowspan="4"|2008 | 25 March | rowspan="3"|Ireland | rowspan="3"|Westlife | rowspan="3"|[[Back Home Tour]] |- | 26 March |- | 25 May |- | 29 November | United Kingdom | [[Coldplay]] | [[Viva la Vida Tour]] |- ! 2009 | 28 February | United States | [[Metallica]] | [[World Magnetic Tour]] | [[Machine Head (band)|Machine Head]]
[[The Sword]] |- ! rowspan="4"| 2010 | 9 May | rowspan="2"|Ireland | rowspan="2"|Westlife | rowspan="2"|[[Where We Are Tour (Westlife)|Where We Are Tour]] |- | 10 May |- | 13 May | Barbados | [[Rihanna]] | [[Last Girl on Earth Tour]] |- | 4 June | United States | [[Lady Gaga]] | [[Monster Ball Tour]] | [[Semi Precious Weapons]] | colspan="2" {{Unknown}} |- ! rowspan="4"|2011 | 28 March | rowspan="2"|Ireland | rowspan="2"|Westlife | rowspan="2"|[[Gravity Tour]] |- | 29 March |- | 5 November | United States | [[Britney Spears]] | [[Femme Fatale Tour]] | [[Joe Jonas]] |- | 19 November | Barbados | [[Rihanna]] | [[Loud Tour]] |- ! rowspan="3"|2012 | 13 May | rowspan="3"|Ireland | rowspan="3"|Westlife | rowspan="3"|[[Greatest Hits Tour (Westlife)|Greatest Hits Tour]] |- | 19 May |- | 12 June |- ! rowspan="2"|2014 | 30 March | United States | [[Justin Timberlake]] | [[The 20/20 Experience World Tour]] | DJ Freestyle |- | 13 November | Australia | [[Kylie Minogue]] | [[Kiss Me Once Tour]] | Third Party |- ! 2015 | 28 February | Ireland | [[The Script]] | [[No Sound Without Silence Tour]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sheffieldtelegraph.co.uk/whats-on/music/the-script-wow-thousands-of-fans-in-sheffield-1-7132567|title=The Script wow thousands of fans in Sheffield|first=Chris|last=Burn|work=Sheffield Telegraph|date=1 March 2015|accessdate=6 October 2016}} | [[Colton Avery]]
[[Tinie Tempah]] | colspan="2" {{Unknown}} |- ! 2016 | 5 April | Australia | [[5 Seconds of Summer]] | [[Sounds Live Feels Live World Tour]]{{cite web|url=http://www.key103.co.uk/music/news/5-seconds-of-summer-announce-april-2016-arena-tour-tickets/|title=5 Seconds of Summer announce April 2016 arena tour - TICKETS|work=Key 103|date=13 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/whats-on/win-meet-5-seconds-of-summer-at-sheffield-arena-1-7821258|title=WIN: Meet 5 Seconds Of Summer at Sheffield Arena|first=Graham|last=Walker|work=The Star|date=28 March 2016|accessdate=6 October 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://attitude.co.uk/review-5-seconds-of-summer-at-sheffield-motorpoint-arena/|title=Review: 5 Seconds of Summer at Sheffield Motorpoint Arena|work=Attitude|accessdate=6 October 2016}} | [[Don Broco]]{{cite web|url=http://www.kerrang.com/41623/don-broco-to-support-5-seconds-of-summer/|title=Don Broco to support 5 Seconds of Summer|work=Emily - Kerrang|date=12 March 2016|accessdate=6 October 2016}} |- ! 2017 | 21 June | England | [[Electric Light Orchestra]] | Alone in the Universe Tour |[[Tom Chaplin]] |} ==Other events== [[File:Sheffield Arena Interior.jpg|thumb|right|Sheffield Arena Interior]] The arena also hosts annual events including [[Disney on Ice]] which is held every year over November/December. TV shows such as ''The X Factor'', ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'', ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'' and ''[[Dancing on Ice]]'' visit the arena every year as part of their tours. The arena is a regular venue for some of the worlds best known Comedians such as [[Russell Brand]], [[Lee Evans (comedian)|Lee Evans]], [[Jack Whitehall]], [[Eddie Izzard]] and [[Peter Kay]] who in 2011 played the arena for 5 nights running with all shows selling out within hours of going on sale. The arena has hosted major special high-profile events, including The [[International Indian Film Academy Awards]], which took place on Saturday, 9 June 2007 and was broadcast live around the world. This included a season hosted by the city of [[Sheffield]] and nearby [[Leeds]]. Also, in 2009, the arena hosted the annual [[BBC 1Xtra]] concert and the 2009 [[BBC Sports Personality of the Year]]. The Sheffield Arena is used regular for sporting events and is the home to the city's [[Elite Ice Hockey League]] team, the Sheffield Steelers. The arena has hosted major boxing events such as when [[Joe Calzaghe]] first won his [[WBO]] world title here on 11 October 1997 against former world champion [[Chris Eubank]]. On the same bill Sheffield born [[Naseem Hamed]] defended his WBO title against Jose Badillo. On 26 November 2005 [[Ricky Hatton]] extended his unbeaten record to 40–0, defending his [[IBF]] and [[Ring Magazine]] Junior Welterweight world titles and winning the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] belt by 9th-round knockout against [[Carlos Maussa]]. [[Sheffield]] fighter [[Clinton Woods]] also defended his IBF light-heavyweight title against Mexican [[Julio César González]] on two occasions, winning on points both times. [[Kell Brook]] has had many fights here, his most notable being a fourth-round knockout victory of [[Vyacheslav Senchenko]]. The [[Great Britain men's national basketball team]] played a test match against [[Portugal national basketball team|Portugal]] in that arena in preparation for the 2012 Olympics. The arena has also hosted the [[WWE]] [[UK Rampage]] event in [[UK Rampage (1992)|1992]] and [[UK Rampage (1993)|1993]], as well as [[Rebellion (2000)|Rebellion]] in 2000. Since 2007, it has played host to the [[Premier League Darts]]. ===Sheffield Steelers=== The arena's resident sport team is the [[Sheffield Steelers]] [[ice hockey]] team who play in the [[Elite Ice Hockey League]]. The Steelers have recorded crowds of up to 10,000 in the building with extra seating being installed at the venue. ==Management== The arena is owned by [[Sheffield City Trust]], an independent [[charitable trust|charity]], and managed under contract by the US media giant [[Live Nation UK]]. *'''Security''': Showsec *'''Catering''': In House *'''Stewarding''': Showsec *'''Stage crew''': Showsec *'''Merchandising''': Pantheon Franchise Ltd *'''Medical''': [[British Red Cross]] ==Transport== ===Car=== The arena has car parking available for around 2,000 cars. It is also proximate and connected to junction 34 of the [[M1 motorway]]. ===Tram=== The arena is connected to the [[Sheffield Supertram]] with a stop next to the arena. The main stop is 'Arena'. Across the road at the [[Valley Centertainment]] entertainment complex there is also another tram stop. ==Competition with First Direct Arena== [[File:Construction of Leeds Arena (1st February 2012) 005.JPG|thumb|right|The construction of the [[First Direct Arena]] (pictured) caused controversy in Sheffield.]] For nearly two decades Sheffield Arena had been the only major concert and sporting venue in the Yorkshire region, this however changed as the city of [[Leeds]] has its own [[First Direct Arena|arena]] of comparable size which directly competes with Sheffield Arena. The arena's construction caused controversy because it was partly funded by the government through [[Yorkshire Forward]], a regional development agency, whereas the Sheffield Arena attracted all funding independently with no help from the government. The owners of Sheffield Arena as well as [[Clive Betts]], the MP for [[Sheffield Attercliffe]], expressed opposition over Yorkshire Forward's funding of the First Direct Arena which they claimed would cause considerable economic damage to Sheffield Arena, East Sheffield and Sheffield/[[South Yorkshire]] itself, Yorkshire Forward dismissed these claims and stated that the arena would bring economic growth not only to Leeds and [[West Yorkshire]] but to the entire region. Fears that the construction of the [[First Direct Arena]] would lead to a significant reduction in concerts at Sheffield appear to be well founded with many tours in 2014 not going to Sheffield including [[Bangerz Tour|Miley Cyrus]], [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Robbie Williams]], [[The Eagles]] and [[Pearl Jam]]. However fears that the arena would suffer from fewer customers as residents of Leeds will no longer have to travel to Sheffield to attend concerts appear unfounded as attendance at concerts remains high. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Sheffield Arena}} *{{Official website|http://www.flydsaarena.co.uk/}} {{Navboxes|list1= {{Live Nation}} {{Indoor arenas UK}} {{SheffieldStructures}} {{Elite Ice Hockey League Venues}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} [[Category:Attercliffe]] [[Category:Basketball venues in England]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Sheffield]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in England]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in England]] [[Category:Sheffield Sharks]] [[Category:Sports venues in Sheffield]] [[Category:Darts venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1991]] [[Category:1991 establishments in England]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Britney Europe.jpg|thumb|Rise in popularity of thongs among younger girls has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto">[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2002/06/16/LV184497.DTL Grin and bare it], San Francisco Chronicles</ref> Picture shows Britney Spears performing, 2011.]] The '''social impact of thong underwear''' has been covered extensively in the media, ranging from a ban on wearing [[thong (clothing)|thong]]s to thongs for the underaged. The rise of thong usage has been asserted by Christian minister Oneil McQuick to be linked to a rise of [[sexualization]] in society,<ref>{{cite book|first=Oneil|last=McQuick|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ewm93pO7YQcC&pg=PT1&dq=thong+society+sex|title=The Sexuality Series|page=29|publisher=L.I.M Publishing|year=2007|isbn=1-4196-4225-1}}</ref> and by Christian writer Philo Thelos to be linked to a rise in a desire to go unclothed.<ref>{{cite book|first=Philo|last=Thelos|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KpYJYeKiss8C&pg=PA52&dq=thong+society+sex|title=Divine Sex: Liberating Sex from Religious Tradition|page=52|publisher=Trafford Publishing|year=2003|isbn=1-55395-400-9}}</ref>
== Overview == [[File:Thong (cropped).jpg|thumb|Woman wearing a T-back thong in [[Sunrise, Florida]], USA in 2006]]
When discussing the trend of wearing thongs, Christian writer Sharon Daugherty comments in her book ''What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?'' that the fashion industry "may have changed the mindset of our society",<ref>{{cite book|first=Sharon|last=Daugherty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3kx5Z42GPYC||title=What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?|page=61|publisher=Destiny Image Publishers|year=2006|isbn=0-7684-2368-6}}</ref> which was followed by the observation that "the whole idea of wearing so that no panty line or bumps can show isn't substantiated" and that "the thong was created by fashion designers to arouse sexual thoughts".{{sfn|Daugherty|2006|page=63}}
[[Monica Lewinsky]] gave evidence during the [[Lewinsky scandal]] that she was flirting with [[Bill Clinton]] in [[Leon Panetta]]'s office, and that she lifted her jacket to show him the straps of her thong underwear above her pants.<ref>{{cite web | last = Starr | first = Kenneth | author-link = Ken Starr | title = Report to the House on President Clinton: Narrative Pt. II: Initial Sexual Encounters (extract) | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/icreport/6narritii.htm | website = washingtonpost.com | publisher = [[The Washington Post]] | date = September 1998 }}</ref> Some of the news media in America used thong underwear as a metonym for smut in the [[Starr Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/1998/09/the_thong_show.html|title=The Thong Show|date=22 September 1998|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref> According to feminist commentator [[Carrie Lukas]], Lewinsky "with her thong-snapping seduction, forever changed the image of the D.C. junior staffer from aspiring policy wonk to sexual temptress."<ref>{{citation | last = Lukas | first = Carrie | author-link = Carrie Lukas | contribution = Sex: love's got something to do with it | editor-last = Lukas | editor-first = Carrie | editor-link = Carrie Lukas | title = The politically incorrect guide to women, sex, and feminism | page = 21 | publisher = Regency Publishing | location = Washington, DC Lanham, Maryland | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781596980037 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=BVf_dCr023IC&pg=PA21&dq=thong+woman+sex&lr=&ei=sw4FSOahHIT6yATl3pj-Dw&sig=OCS8-3Pm9Npbe4q3ZRklqehUVzE#PPA21,M1 Preview.]</ref>
Marketing analysts Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly observed in the book ''Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand'' that thong brands are riding on the wide media coverage of thongs to create [[Word of mouth|buzz]].<ref>Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sf85DYe9140C&pg=PA116&dq=thong+society+sex&lr=&ei=4vcESNDMF5jWyATNt_D9Dg&sig=f7ebSu-0y8UlAac7H8tqhsOIUiw Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand], Page 116, John Wiley and Sons, 2003, {{ISBN|0-471-27345-7}}</ref> Photographer [[Lauren Greenfield]] wrote in her book ''Girl Culture'', "Understanding the [[dialectic]] between the extreme and the mainstream – the anorexic and the dieter, the stripper and the teenager who bares her midriff or wears a thong – is essential to understanding contemporary feminine identity."<ref>Lauren Greenfield, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TUT9vKPr4_YC&pg=PT155&dq=thong+britney+spears&lr=&ei=TxEFSNTxLYOOywSSjuCiDw&sig=gCRLKGJiBIpHS_FdG9K02x9uk4k Girl Culture], Chronicle Books, 2002, {{ISBN|0-8118-3790-4}}</ref>
In 2004, political commentator Cedric Muhammad wrote in essay ''The Thong versus the Veil'', "We wondered at the end of the day, of the two groups of women most prominently featured on American TV these days, who gains more respect for their intellect and spirit – the Afghan woman who is so totally veiled that you can't even see her eyes or the Black woman in the R&B and Hip-Hop video who dances while wearing a bikini and thong?"<ref>Laura Flanders (ed.), [https://books.google.com/books?id=gg5NNztsUooC&pg=PA180&dq=thong+culutre+sex&lr=&ei=DhgFSLXXPJTAzATBy_yXDg&sig=QZNRmkA0_poI66Hywqj9tkkPYyg#PPA181,M1 The W Effect: Bush's War on Women], Page 181, Feminist Press, 2004, {{ISBN|1-55861-471-0}}</ref>
==School restrictions== The dress code for [[St. Ambrose Academy]], a Roman Catholic middle school and high school in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], specifically addresses swimsuits with "thong-cut legs" as inappropriate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |title=Ambrose Academy website |publisher=Ambroseacademy.org |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727005219/http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> At [[Dixon High School (California)|Dixon High School]] in [[Dixon, California]], the dress code specifies that all undergarments – specifically listing thongs, along with [[bra]]s and [[briefs]] – must be covered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |title=Dixon High School |publisher=Dhs.dixonusd.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011210154/http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |archivedate=11 October 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[University of Victoria]] Law School briefly put the school logo on thongs, but quickly pulled them from sale after controversy sprung up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030810135944/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archivedate=2003-08-10 |title=Indissent, University of Victoria |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=10 August 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1999 a [[Miami University]] male professor was banned from using the school's recreation center because he refused to stop wearing thong swimwear. The professor challenged the school in court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://enquirer.com/editions/1999/03/02/loc_professor_sues_miami.html|title= Professor sues Miami U to keep thong swimsuit |date=2 March 1999|accessdate=6 January 2016|publisher=[[Cincinnati Enquirer]]}}</ref> In 2000 a [[Salinas, California|Salinas]] High School principal was in the center of a variety of controversies including bans on clothing to the extent that "thong panties were unofficially banned." One student alleged that she was given a dress-code violation note for wearing a thong.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/12.14.00/dresscode-0050.html |title=Metro Active |publisher=Metro Active |date=14 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> This story made national headlines in the United States.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly">[https://archive.is/20070628153120/http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/articles/7128/print Monterey County Weekly] </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0009/13/tod.04.html |title=CNN transcript |publisher=Transcripts.cnn.com |date=13 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2002, a female high school vice principal in San Diego physically checked up to 100 female students' underwear<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |title=Channel 10 news |publisher=10news.com |date=17 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120184346/http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |archivedate=20 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> as they entered the school for a dance, with or without student permission, causing an uproar among students and some parents and eliciting an investigation by the school into the vice principal's conduct.<ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011160853/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> In her defense, the vice principal said the checks were for student safety and not specifically because of the wearing of thongs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020605-9999_2m5thong.html |title=> News > North County - 2 on RB High staff faulted for checks of undergarments |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-05 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020616-9999_2m16thong.html |title=> News > North County - Demotion possible for assistant principal |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-16 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/06/18/thong-demotion.htm |title=USA Today |work=USA Today |date=18 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/06/18/national/main512654.shtml |title=CBS News |publisher=CBS News |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214172315/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html |date=14 December 2007 }}</ref> In 2003, the [[head teacher]] of a British primary school voiced her concern after learning that female students as young as 10 were wearing thong underwear to school. This incident led to a media debate about the appropriateness of thong underwear marketed to young girls.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2943874.stm |title=Bbc (Uk) |publisher=BBC News |date=28 May 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
==Sports== The [[University of California]] [[4-H]] program specifically forbids "string, thong or crochet" swimsuits for women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |title=University of California, Davis |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208005132/http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |archivedate=8 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> For men, the dress code specifies "swim trunks only (no shorts, cut-off pants, or Speedos)." A similar policy by [[Virginia]] [[FCCLA]] bans "skimpy bikini or thong type suits" for women and specifies "swim trunks" for men ("no speedos").<ref>[http://www.me.vccs.edu/fccla/documents/DressCode_000.doc VCCS FCCLA website]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref>
In 2001, [[Vicky Botwright]], then 16th seeded in women's squash circuit and dubbed the "Lancashire Hot Bot", was prohibited by the [[Women's International Squash Players Association]] (WISPA) from wearing a thong and a sports bra in the British Open Championships.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |title=All thong wrong @ BBC Sports Online |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021203211540/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |archivedate=3 December 2002 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2004, Alexander Putnam competed in the [[London Marathon]] in a green thong and painted as a tropical tree to protest against logging in Congo.<ref>[http://www.rainforestfoundationuk.org/s-%93Mara-thong%94%20Man%20runs%20from%20Congo%20loggers "Mara-thong" Man runs from Congo loggers], Rainforest Foundation</ref>
[[Female bodybuilder]]s in America are prohibited from wearing thong or T-back swimsuits if contests are being filmed for television, otherwise they are allowed to do so by certain fitness organizations.<ref>Maria R. Lowe, ''Women of steel: female bodybuilders and the struggle for self-definition'', page 191, New York University Press, 1998, {{ISBN|0-8147-5094-X}}</ref>
==Bans== In October 2002, Florida officials banned thongs from [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] and other public beaches.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2003-01-05-spring-break-usat_x.htm|title=Alcohol-soaked spring break lures students abroad|newspaper=USA Today|author=Donna Leinwand|date=2003-01-05}}</ref>
==Thongs for younger girls== The 2000s saw a rise in the popularity of thongs among younger girls, who have been dubbed "thong feminists" by comedian [[Janeane Garofalo]]. The trend has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto"/> In 2002 [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] released a line of thong underwear targeted for girls ages 10–16, though critics pointed out that children as young as seven could fit one of the thongs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/05/22/news/companies/abercrombie/ |title=CNN Money |publisher=CNN |date=28 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="JS Online">[http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 JS Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114063620/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 |date=14 November 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0DE3D9163BF937A15756C0A9649C8B63 |title=New York Times |work=New York Times |date=24 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |first=Leslie |last=Kaufman}}</ref> A spokesman for A&F, Hampton Carney, stated that he could list "at least 100 reasons why a young girl would want thong underwear."<ref name="JS Online"/> This controversy spawned a great deal of free publicity for Abercrombie, including a chain letter that received wide circulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |title=Break the Chain website |publisher=Breakthechain.org |date=6 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122041435/http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |archivedate=22 January 2012 }}</ref> British retailer [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]] produced child-size thongs and padded [[Brassiere|bras]] for girls as young as nine, eliciting a similar response from the public.<ref>{{cite news|author=20 Feb 2007 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/20/ngirls220.xml |title=(UK) |publisher=The Telegraph |date=20 February 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=This Is Money |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=363110&in_page_id=1770&in_a_source=&ito=1490 |title=(UK) |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=9 July 2001 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> [[Etam UK|Etam]], another British retailer, produced [[Sheer (textile)|sheer]] [[Top (clothing)|top]]s and thong underwear for girls of similar age.<ref>[http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2003140951,00.html The Sun (UK)]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref> In Japan, photobooks and DVDs of underaged girls in T-back thongs has become popular as "T-back Junior Idols", which has come under scorn as a new form of child pornography.<ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070503f1.html Photos of preteen girls in thongs now big business], Japan Times</ref>
==Indecent exposure== * In August 2007 a man in Texas was arrested for [[indecent exposure]] for being naked in his own backyard. He reported that he was in fact wearing a thong and was not naked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |title=San Marcos Daily Record "Backyard exposure leads to arrest" |publisher=Sanmarcosrecord.com |date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907090215/http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |archivedate=7 September 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Other impacts== * A [[YMCA]] management firm has addressed thongs in dress code policy, stating (in different areas) that "thong-type wear isn't an issue." Additionally, an email from a university fitness center implied that there are safety issues ("thongs on bike seats") that would need to be addressed.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly"/> * In 2007 a man who had broken into a home wearing only a thong was sentenced to 20 years in prison for burglary and attempted rape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|title=WPCO 9 (ABC) "Thong-Wearing Burglar Sentenced"|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215025154/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|archivedate=15 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |title=WKRC 12 (CW) "Thong Robber Sentenced to Prison Time" |publisher=Local12.com |date=24 July 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518091250/http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |archivedate=18 May 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> He pleaded "guilty but mentally ill" at the May trial and was sentenced in July. * In 2007 the [[Tennessee]] Department of Correction banned prison visitors from wearing thong or g-string underwear. In the words of Correction Commissioner George Little, prisoners "don't need any help getting turned on."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290945,00.html |title=Fox News "Tennessee Bans Prison Visitors From Wearing G-Strings, Sexy Lingerie" |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=1 January 2012 |date=7 December 2011}}</ref> * After the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]], thousands of thongs were donated to relief organizations sending relief packages to [[Sri Lanka]]. These were largely discarded amongst the influx of more culturally sensitive and functional utilitarian clothing items. * During photography for [[Google Street View]], a woman in a thong was one of the images discovered that caused consternation over the project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |title=» Google Street View Showing Sunbathing and A Woman’s Thong » Blog Archive » SEO/SEM News |publisher=News.seoreligion.com |date=3 June 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220070543/http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |archive-date=20 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * In 2005, the [[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] reported an incident of female United States military soldiers in Iraq stripping down to their thongs to participate in [[mud wrestling]] as an entertaining show.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html Female soldiers dress down & get dirty for mud romps G.I.S GONE WILD], NY Daily News {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519003450/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html |date=19 May 2008 }}</ref>
==Popular culture==
* In 2000, [[R&B]] singer [[Sisqó]] recorded the "[[Thong Song]]" on his ''[[Unleash the Dragon]]'' album. * Writer-director Glen Weiss made three movies titled the ''[[Thong Girl]]'', based on the comic book of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lloyd DeBerry |url=http://www.thonggirlfilms.com/ |title=Thong Girl |publisher=Thonggirlfilms.com |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> The story of the films revolved around the Thong Girl, an independent [[superhero]]. Parts of the film were shot in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s mayor's office in 2007.<ref>[http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm In Dissent] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011172530/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> * Beermaker [[Rolling Rock]] aired a commercial poking fun of male thong wearers during [[Super Bowl|Super Bowl XLI]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splendad.com/ads/show/443-Rolling-Rock-Man-Thong-Apology |title=SplendAD |publisher=SplendAD |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> * [[Shefali Zariwala]], a model in [[India]], became known as the "thong girl" for her performance in the music video of the song ''Kaanta Laga''.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/bangalore-times/im-indias-original-thong-girl/articleshow/1874777.cms 'I'm India's original thong girl'], Times of India</ref> The album sold two million copies and the music video became an overnight success in India.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2003/s1013035.htm Indian Government censors music videos], Australian Broadcasting Corporation</ref> * In 2008, a diamond studded thong worth US$122,000 was featured in a Singapore lingerie fashion show. It had 518 brilliant-cut diamonds, totaling {{convert|30|carat|g}}, studded into the front of a black lace thong in a floral pattern, as well as 27 white gold tassels hanging off it.<ref>[http://in.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idINSIN13091520080403 Diamond thong shown to the throng] Reuters</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Fashion|Sociology}} *[[Thong (clothing)]] *[[G-string]] *[[Whale tail]] *[[Sexual objectification]] *[[Sexual revolution]] *[[Underwear as outerwear]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
